title: Homomorphic equivalence
summary: In the mathematics of graph theory, two graphs, G and H, are called homomorphically equivalent if there exists a graph homomorphism f : G → H {\displaystyle f\colon G\to H} and a graph homomorphism g : H → G {\displaystyle g\colon H\to G} . An example usage of this notion is that any two cores of a graph are homomorphically equivalent.
